title: 105_hr3231
content: The Act may be cited as the "Honduran Refugee Immigration Fairness Act of 1998". It involves the adjustment of status of certain Honduran nationals. The "Honduran Refugee Immigration Fairness Act of 1998" allows for the adjustment of status for eligible aliens to lawful permanent residence, if they apply before April 1, 2000, and meet certain criteria. The "Honduran Refugee Immigration Fairness Act of 1998" allows eligible aliens to apply for adjustment of status, even if they have been previously ordered to leave the United States under the Immigration and Nationality Act. If the application is granted, the order will be canceled; if denied, the order remains in effect. Aliens eligible for adjustment of status under the "Honduran Refugee Immigration Fairness Act of 1998" must have been physically present in the United States on December 31, 1995, and for at least 1 year prior to filing the application. The Attorney General can provide regulations for aliens with final deportation orders to seek a stay of removal. The Attorney General can authorize aliens in deportation proceedings to seek a stay of removal based on an application for adjustment of status. Aliens can also be allowed to work in the US while their adjustment of status application is pending. The Attorney General can authorize aliens in deportation proceedings to seek a stay of removal based on an application for adjustment of status. Aliens can also work in the US while their adjustment of status application is pending, with authorization granted if the application exceeds 180 days without denial. Additionally, spouses and children of aliens from Honduras can have their status adjusted to that of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence. The alien can apply for adjustment of status to that of a lawful permanent resident if they meet certain criteria, including physical presence in the US for at least 1 year, being physically present in the US when the application is filed, and meeting all other eligibility requirements for an immigrant visa. The Attorney General shall provide applicants for adjustment of status with the same administrative review rights and procedures as those applying for adjustment of status under section 245 of the Immigration and Nationality Act or aliens in removal proceedings under section 240 of the Act. The Attorney General's determination on an alien's status adjustment under the Act is final and not subject to judicial review. When an alien is granted lawful permanent residence status, the Secretary of State is not required to reduce the number of immigrant visas available. The Immigration and Nationality Act definitions apply unless specified otherwise in this Act. The Attorney General's powers in immigration enforcement are not affected by the alien's eligibility for permanent residence status under this section. The alien can still seek permanent residence under other laws if eligible.
